title: For Sale/Trade:  Hey .22 ammo hoarders...
postcontent:
Ok so you can get your 22 ammo of the delivery truck at Walmart or Dicks or wherever for $0.05 per round and then list it for double that. Well here are some good reasons not to do that. 

1. Time and fuel. Yeah it costs time and $ to buy it and it costs time and $ to sell it. Buying in limited retail store quantities (1 brick at a time) gives you less than McD's lunch money. You are not "doubling your money" selling at double the price you bought it for. 
2. Bulk ammo does not store forever. In 10-12 years all your ammo stash will be trash. Bulk ammo (in loose rounds that touch each) start to corrode and oxidize in as little as a decade since the lead is touching brass is touching cooper etc. google it. 
3. What goes up must come down. Hoarding goes up= costs go up and later the market gets flooded with old unused product. Once more people start realizing they don't need or can't sell this older ammo then market rate drops below $0.02 per round. 
4. 22 gougers inflate retail rates for retailers. Retailers see individual people posting 22 on the Internet for high prices so they adjust their pricing to meet the gougers so they can keep their inventory longer and get in some some gouging themselves just due to hype and talk. 
5. This ammo hype is getting attention from lawmakers and congress is getting pressure to pass laws that individuals must have a license to sell ammunition. Sounds ridiculous but it could happen with all these democrats. If this does happen then retailers will have the same advantage forever that gougers had for a couple years. 

So there I did my part to help limit this 22 ammo stupidity and ridiculousness. Please keep your ammo fresh (less than 5 years) and don't buy 10X more than you need.
